param.name: option
param.label: Option
param.description: Select what information to return.

option.label: REMOTE_ADDR
option.description: The IP address from which the user is viewing the current page.

option.label: HTTP_REFERER
option.description: The address of the page (if any) which referred the user agent to the current page. This is set by the user agent. Not all user agents will set this, and some provide the ability to modify HTTP_REFERER as a feature. In short, it cannot really be trusted.

option.label: REMOTE_HOST
option.description: The Host name from which the user is viewing the current page. The reverse dns lookup is based off the REMOTE_ADDR of the user.

option.label: REMOTE_PORT
option.description: The port being used on the user's machine to communicate with the web server.

option.label: REMOTE_USER
option.description: The authenticated user.

option.label: PHP_SELF
option.description: The filename of the currently executing script, relative to the document root.

option.label: GATEWAY_INTERFACE
option.description: Revision of the CGI specification the server is using; i.e. 'CGI/1.1'

option.label: SERVER_ADDR
option.description: The IP address of the server under which the current script is executing.

option.label: SERVER_NAME
option.description: The name of the server host under which the current script is executing. If the script is running on a virtual host, this will be the value defined for that virtual host.

option.label: SERVER_SOFTWARE
option.description: Server identification string, given in the headers when responding to requests.

option.label: SERVER_PROTOCOL
option.description: Name and revision of the information protocol via which the page was requested; i.e. 'HTTP/1.0'

option.label: REQUEST_METHOD
option.description: Which request method was used to access the page; i.e. 'GET', 'HEAD', 'POST', 'PUT'.

option.label: REQUEST_TIME
option.description: The timestamp of the start of the request. Available since PHP 5.1.0.

option.label: REQUEST_TIME_FLOAT
option.description: The timestamp of the start of the request, with microsecond precision. Available since PHP 5.4.0.

option.label: QUERY_STRING
option.description: The query string, if any, via which the page was accessed.

option.label: DOCUMENT_ROOT
option.description: The document root directory under which the current script is executing, as defined in the server's configuration file.

option.label: HTTP_ACCEPT
option.description: Contents of the Accept: header from the current request, if there is one.

option.label: HTTP_ACCEPT_CHARSET
option.description: Contents of the Accept-Charset: header from the current request, if there is one. Example: 'iso-8859-1,*,utf-8'.

option.label: HTTP_ACCEPT_ENCODING
option.description: Contents of the Accept-Encoding: header from the current request, if there is one. Example: 'gzip'.

option.label: HTTP_ACCEPT_LANGUAGE
option.description: Contents of the Accept-Language: header from the current request, if there is one. Example: 'en'.

option.label: HTTP_CONNECTION
option.description: Contents of the Connection: header from the current request, if there is one. Example: 'Keep-Alive'.

option.label: HTTP_HOST
option.description: Contents of the Host: header from the current request, if there is one.

option.label: HTTP_USER_AGENT
option.description: Contents of the User-Agent: header from the current request, if there is one. This is a string denoting the user agent which is accessing the page. A typical example is: Mozilla/4.5 [en] (X11; U; Linux 2.2.9 i586). Among other things, you can use this value with get_browser() to tailor your page's output to the capabilities of the user agent.

option.label: HTTPS
option.description: Set to a non-empty value if the script was queried through the HTTPS protocol.

option.label: REDIRECT_REMOTE_USER
option.description: The authenticated user if the request is internally redirected.

option.label: SCRIPT_FILENAME
option.description: The absolute pathname of the currently executing script.

option.label: SERVER_ADMIN
option.description: The value given to the SERVER_ADMIN (for Apache) directive in the web server configuration file. If the script is running on a virtual host, this will be the value defined for that virtual host.

option.label: SERVER_PORT
option.description: The port on the server machine being used by the web server for communication. For default setups, this will be '80'; using SSL, for instance, will change this to whatever your defined secure HTTP port is.

option.label: SERVER_SIGNATURE
option.description: String containing the server version and virtual host name which are added to server-generated pages, if enabled.

option.label: PATH_TRANSLATED
option.description: Filesystem- (not document root-) based path to the current script, after the server has done any virtual-to-real mapping.

option.label: SCRIPT_NAME
option.description: Contains the current script's path. This is useful for pages which need to point to themselves. The __FILE__ constant contains the full path and filename of the current (i.e. included) file.

option.label: REQUEST_URI
option.description: The URI which was given in order to access this page; for instance, '/index.html'.

option.label: PHP_AUTH_DIGEST
option.description: When doing Digest HTTP authentication, this variable is set to the 'Authorization' header sent by the client (which you should then use to make the appropriate validation).

option.label: PHP_AUTH_USER
option.description: When doing HTTP authentication, this variable is set to the username provided by the user.

option.label: PHP_AUTH_PW
option.description: When doing HTTP authentication, this variable is set to the password provided by the user.

option.label: AUTH_TYPE
option.description: When doing HTTP authentication, this variable is set to the authentication type.

option.label: PATH_INFO
option.description: Contains any client-provided pathname information trailing the actual script filename but preceding the query string, if available. For instance, if the current script was accessed via the URL https://www.example.com/php/path_info.php/some/stuff?foo=bar, then $_SERVER['PATH_INFO'] would contain /some/stuff.

option.label: ORIG_PATH_INFO
option.description: Original version of 'PATH_INFO' before processed by PHP.
